title: Economic Structure of the Roman Empire
subtitle: Trade, Currency, and Social Hierarchy
img_alt_text: Ancient Roman coins and a map of trade routes

body.description: The Roman Empire boasted extensive trade networks that connected it to remote regions, including Asia, Africa, and Northern Europe. These networks facilitated the exchange of goods such as spices, silk, and precious metals, underpinning the empire's economy.

Roman currency, including the denarius, played a crucial role in facilitating trade and commerce throughout the empire. The economy was diverse, featuring agriculture, mining, and manufacturing as key sectors.

The economic structure was closely tied to the social hierarchy, with slaves and freedmen at the bottom performing labor-intensive tasks, while the patrician class engaged in governance and military leadership, influencing economic policies and distribution of wealth.
